Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: They organize immediate support and counseling for community members facing a crisis, such as a natural disaster or sudden loss.
Story: I sat on the edge of my bed, phone in hand, staring at the blinking cursor in the message box. My stepmother had texted earlier, asking if I could call her and Dad this weekend. “We miss you,” she wrote, “just want to hear your voice.” I knew how much it meant to them, especially since I’d moved out and started my work as a pastor. But just as I was about to hit send, my phone buzzed again—this time, it was a member of my congregation. Their house had been damaged in the storm last night, and they needed help, comfort, and guidance. I was expected to organize support, offer prayers, and be present for them, right now. My heart twisted. I wanted to be the caring step-child my parents hoped for, but my congregation needed me, too. The weight of both expectations pressed down on me, and I felt torn, unable to give fully to either side. I stared at my phone, caught between two worlds, unsure which call to make first.
